All of these individuals have left a lasting legacy in the fight for equality and social justice, and inspire us to remember history and continue their important work today.

Former federal judge Damon Keith was a champion for civil rights and equality. A lifelong Detroit resident and one of the most prominent black federal judges, Keith was beloved across Michigan and America. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IfW8XsAQtJWo.jpg

A brilliant inventor, Elijah McCoy held over 50 U.S. patents. His incredible work has inspired generations of inventors, so much that the Midwest Regional U.S. Patent and Trademark office in Detroit is named after him! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IfIpXsAE79aA.jpg

Clifton Wharton Jr. was a trailblazer for African-Americans in education. He was named @michiganstateu's first black President in 1970, making him the first black president of a major U.S. research university. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9Ie6dXYAAQd0C.jpg

The first black school teacher in Flint, Lois Holt was committed to the civil rights movement. She and her husband mortgaged their home in 1957 to transport Flint residents to demonstrate in Alabama following Rosa Parks' arrest, giving a voice to those in her community. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IeuIXkAA_c0i.jpg

Lem Tucker was the first black student body president at Central Michigan University. Tucker went on to be one of NBC's first black TV reporters in 1965 and won two Emmy Awards later in his career for his reporting of black America and hunger in the U.S. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IeezWoActFom.jpg

Otis M. Smith was a trailblazer in the legal community. As the first African-American appointed to the Michigan Supreme Court, Smith was a public servant who was very active in civic organizations. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IeOlXUAAv3rQ.jpg

Erma Henderson was the first black woman elected to the Detroit City Council in 1972. She fought for equality in the workplace and the judicial system.

Henderson led the effort to pass comprehensive state legislation to end the discriminatory practice of redlining in lending. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IeBSWsAAB0P_.jpg

The Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin, was a GRAMMY Award winner and recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom who impacted generations of Americans. A singer and civil rights activist from Detroit, Franklin's legacy extends beyond music. She is so loved and missed. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER9IdxNXsAAm4gN.jpg
As we wrap up #BlackHistoryMonth, I‚Äôd like to highlight some of the extraordinary men and women of Michigan who have led the fight for civil rights and equality.

Stagecoach Mary, the first black woman to serve as a mail carrier, delivered post by stagecoach across MT for 8 years. Beloved by the community and feared by thieves, her tough reputation preceded her, and was always known for getting the job done right. #BlackHistoryMonth

James Presley Ball, a daguerreotyper, abolitionist, and businessman, moved to Helena in 1887. He opened a studio and photographed the construction of our State Capitol building. Active in MT politics, Ball was elected to the MT Republican convention in 1894. #BlackHistoryMonth

Alma Smith Jacobs, a librarian and civil rights advocate, cofounded the Montana Advisory Committee for U.S. Civil Rights Commission and Humanities Montana. Alma was the first African American to serve as Montana State Librarian in 1973. #BlackHistoryMonth

James Dorsey, a lawyer and civil rights activist, was the first black student to graduate from both the undergraduate and law programs at @umontana. His legacy lives on with the Dorsey-King Memorial Scholarship, honoring students committed to racial justice. #BlackHistoryMonth

Although #BlackHistoryMonth is coming to an end, we recognize the contributions of America‚Äôs African American community year-round. Here‚Äôs a look at just a few of the remarkable black men and women of MT who have contributed to our great history and the fight for racial justice:

As we end #BlackHistoryMonth, I‚Äôm remembering the first responders who led the way for those of us who followed. We stand on the shoulders of giants.

We also give thanks to all our first responders. We know that when they are as diverse as our community, we are all safer.
Davell Davis, Jimmy Hawkins, Harley Leak, Tim Jackson, Willie Green and Samuel Williams were Orlando‚Äôs first Black @OrlandoFireDept firefighters.
Louis Crooms, Leroy Williams, Tommy Ward, Jimmie Randle, Luis Demps, Roosevelt Sealey and William Williams were the first Black deputies for the @OrangeCoSheriff.

Despite these challenges, they served Orlando with professionalism and distinction.

Belvin Perry Sr., Richard Arthur Jones, John W. Jordan, Otha Lee Kelly, Mayo Howard and Gainous Wright were the first Black officers for the @OrlandoPolice

When @OrlandoPolice‚Äôs first Black officers‚ÄîBelvin Perry Sr. and Richard Arthur Jones‚Äîbegan their careers in 1951, they had secondhand cars and no radios.

They could issue arrests, but if the suspect was white, they weren‚Äôt allowed to take them to jail. #BlackHistoryMonth #BHM http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER-0e-BXsAEC4EU.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER-0e-BXUAAIB9e.jpg
